message: I would like to create a custom model field that does not require a db column.  Weird I know, but it's true.  I've searched the docs and have only found how to avoid the initial sql that builds the column.  http://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/howto/custom-model-fields/#django.db.models.Field.db_type
How would the object know what file it has if you don't store it?
you can add an extra field in your ModelForm without affecting your db
Since you don't store it, its not really a "model field" in terms on Django - doesn't that just make it a class property?

I have a Files model that stores content_type and object_id.  I'm using this Files model to hold all file objects.  Now I want to associate files to a random model.  Let's say a person object.  So within the Person model I would really like to have have a CustomField() that updates the Files model DB and not it's own Person model DB.
Sounds like a job for a very very custom field class that emulated both a foreignkey and a file field.
Alternatively add a FileField to the form yourself and then handle putting it in the correct model in your code
Thank you everyone. I really appreciate the help!  It's comforting to know that this is not an ideal request.  I was worried I was racking my brain for no reason.
@eloy what is the advantage of this "CustomField" over using a GenericForeignKey?
The advantage of the CustomField is that it's Many-to-One when I use the custom field on the Model as opposed to One-to-Many.  Only difference, I think.
